key_insight: InfSplign is a training-free, inference-time technique that improves how text-to-image diffusion models respect spatial relations by iteratively adjusting the denoising noise using a compound loss applied at every step.
problem_solved: Text-to-image diffusion models often ignore or misplace spatial relations described in prompts because training data lacks fine-grained spatial supervision and text embeddings do not reliably encode spatial semantics.
method: Inference-time, training-free algorithm that intervenes during the denoising loop of pretrained diffusion models.
At each denoising step, compute a compound loss that balances spatial alignment objectives with fidelity/prompt-consistency terms and backpropagate to adjust the noise input.
Plug-and-play: compatible with existing T2I models and prompts, requiring no model fine-tuning or additional supervised data.
impact: Enables practitioners to get more spatially accurate generations (better placement, relations, and layouts) without retraining models, improving reliability for design, UI mockups, and scene-composition applications.
visual_elements: Before/after image pairs showing the same prompt where spatial relations are incorrect vs corrected by InfSplign.
Flowchart of the diffusion denoising loop with a highlighted step showing the compound loss computation and noise correction applied at each iteration.
Iconic diagram breaking the compound loss into components (spatial alignment vs fidelity) with brief captions.
Overlayed attention or heatmap visualizations showing improved object placement and relational accuracy.
paper_title: InfSplign: Inference-Time Spatial Alignment of Text-to-Image Diffusion Models
paper_authors: Sarah Rastegar, Violeta Chatalbasheva, Sieger Falkena, Anuj Singh, Yanbo Wang
